bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur C. Jacobson, February 18, 1949

div1.p: Hench sends Jacobson information regarding Reed's early career. He also refers him to Laura Wood's book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Arthur C. Jacobson, February 18, 1949
div1.opener:
February 18, 1949
Dr. Arthur C. Jacobson, Editor
Medical Times
67 Wall Street
New York 5, New York
My dear Doctor Jacobson:
div1.p:
I have been in Europe for quite a while and have before me now your
letter of October 9 requesting information regarding the early medical career
of Walter Reed. I fear that by now you may have already written your article,
but in the hope the following might still be helpful, I am sending it.

You might wish to consult the book “Walter Reed: Doctor in Uniform”
by Laura N. Wood, (now Mrs. Crosby Roper, 2151 California Street, N. W., Washington,
D. C.) published by Julian Messner, Inc., 1943. This gives some information
about his early career but is not very specific about the dates and places and
to the best of my knowledge, the following is as correct as can be found:
Fall, 1867 - Spring 1868: Attended University of Virginia, senior
Latin and Greek classes but did not graduate in
either branch.
October 1, 1868 - University of Virginia, began the study of medicine.
July 1, 1869 - Received the degree of M.D. from the University of Vir-
ginia. I have Reed's medical diploma in my
possession.
September 1869 - Matriculated as a student of medicine, Bellevue
Hospital Medical College.
December 1869 - While attending medical lectures at Bellevue Hospital
Medical College he took competitive examinations
for the position of Assistant Physician, Infants'
Hospital, Randall's Island, New York.
January 1, 1870 - April 1, 1871 - Assistant physician, Infants' Hospital
Randall's Island.
In Reed's biographical notes of his early career, he twice calls this
the Infants' Hospital. It must have officially been known as the Nursery Hospital
because I have in my possession Reed's diploma from the Nursery Hospital stating
that he had served there as assistant physician from January 1, 1870 to January 1,
1871. I assume the term Infants' Hospital was a nickname. You will see that this
information conflicts with that in your letter where you stated that he served at
a hospital on Randall's Island which was a hospital for the feebleminded and
crippled. Perhaps the Nursery Hospital was a unit of some larger state institution
on Randall's Island. I do not know.
Dr. Arthur C. Jacobson
- 2 -
February 18, 1949
April 1, 1871 (?) - August 1, 1871 - Assistant physician, Kings County
Hospital, Flatbush, Long Island. My date of April 1
is presumptive as Reed states that he held the position on Randall's Island
“until April 1, 1871, was then appointed assistant physician, Kings County
Hospital and remained until August 1, 1871, at which time I resigned.” Apparently
Reed only interned at Kings County Hospital from April 1 to August 1; in other
words, three months and then resigned.
There is an article “Walter Reed at Kings County Hospital” by B. J.
Ficarra, Military Surgeon, Volume 92, pages 552 - 557, May 1943, which discusses
in a vague way Reed's intership there. It does not state the time that he was
at the hospital. Presumably the records did not show it as he was there for
such a short time.
August 1, 1871 - August 1, 1872 - was resident physician and surgeon
at Brooklyn City Hospital, Brooklyn, New York,
from which he received two diplomas, both in my
possession. One from the Board of Trustees and
one from the “Attending Physicians and Surgeons.”
August 1, 1872 (?) - March 1, 1873 - District physician, Department
of Public Charities of New York and Attending
Physician, Eastern Dispensary, New York. The
date of August 1, 1872 is presumptive. Reed says that he was resident surgeon
of the Brooklyn City Hospital until August 1, 1872. “At this time I was appointed
district physician under the Department of Public Charities, New York and
attending physician, Eastern Dispensary, New York, which positions (plural) I
retained until March 1, 1873.”
October 1, 1872 - received second degree of doctor of medicine from
Bellevue Hospital. Obviously he was completing his lectures at the Bellevue
Hospital while doing these various residencies, etc., and finally completed
the requirements.
June 1873 - Appointed Sanitary Inspector, Brooklyn Board of Health.
Apparently he continued this position until....
February 8, 1875 - He took his examination for the Army and entered
the Army very shortly thereafter.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
